title: Is the Earth gradually getting closer to the Sun, farther away, or staying exactly the same? - Quora

response.answer_text: A2A This question has come in many forms on Quora: Is the sun coming closer to the Earth?Is the earth moving closer to the sun?Is it true that each year the earth is getting closer to the sun?Since our orbit is an ellipse, we move closer to (147.1 million km), and farther from the sun (152.1 million km), on a repeating cycle each year. We are closer during the winter and further during the summer months (it’s the opposite seasons in the southern hemisphere). The mean orbital radius is increasing ever so gradually as the sun loses mass. There have been many studies, and many scientific papers written on this subject, and the consensus is that as the sun loses mass, it’s gravitational attraction weakens, resulting in all of the planets moving further away from the sun over the entire lifespan of the sun, but it is nearly imperceptible. It has not been observed, rather it has been calculated mathematically. The best estimates suggest that the Earth is currently moving away from the sun by about 15 cm per year. Since our orbital radius is an average of nearly 150 million km, we won’t notice any difference, and it has little to no effect on our climate. Earth’s orbit around the sun experiences many cyclical changes lasting thousands of years. These cyclical changes have a more profound effect than our orbit’s increasing in radius by a mere 15 cm per year. The Earth has an elliptical orbit around the Sun... something like this...  ​So... it has such an orbit as the Earth moves closer to the Sun sometimes ... and farther from the Sun sometimes. Now, if you are meaning the mean orbital distance of the Earth from the Sun... that is increasing by 15 cm each year since the Sun is slowly losing mass!
